publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: By an Honest Whig Curate. Dr. S────t.
Annoque Domini 1732.
OLD Latimer preaching did fairly describe
A Bishop, who ruled the rest of the Tribe.
But who is the Bishop? and where does he dwell?
Why truly 'tis Satan! a B----p of H-ll:
And he was a Prime-Mate, and he wore a Mitre
Surrounded with Blazons of Sulphur and Nitre.
How nearly this B──p our B──ps resembles!
But his had the Odds, who── believes and who trembles.
Cou'd you see his grim Grace, for a Pound to a Penny
You'd swear it must be the Bab──n of Kil──ny.
Poor Satan will think the Comparison odious,
I wish I could find him out one more commodious:
But this I am sure, the most Rev'rend old Dragon
Has got on the Bench many B──ps Suf──fragan;
And all Men believe he presides there incog
To give them by turns an invisible Jog.
Our Pr──tes puff'd up with Wealth and with Pride,
To Hell on the Backs of the Clergy would ride,
They mounted and labour'd with Whip and with Spur,
In vain! for the Devil a Parson would stir.
So the Commons unhors'd them, and this was their Doom,
On their Crosiers to ride, like a Witch on a Broom.
Tho' they gallop so fast, on the Road you may find 'em
To have left us but three out of twenty behind 'em.
Lord Bolton's good Grace, Lord Car, and Lord Howard,
In spite of the Devil would still be untoward:
They came of good Blood, and would not endure
Their former Companions to beg at the Door.
When Christ was betray'd to Pilate the Prætor,
In a dozen Apostles, but one prov'd a Traytor,
One Traytor alone, and faithful Eleven,
But we can afford you Six Traytors in Seven.
What a Clatter was made 'bout Dividings and Cleavings,
And the Clergy forsooth must take up with their Leavings.
If making Divisions was all their Intent,
They have done it, we thank 'em,--- but not as they meant,
And so may such B──ps for ever divide,
That no honest Heathen would be on their side.
Now should we rejoice, if like Judas the Curst
The Splitters of Parsons in sunder should burst.
Now hear an Allusion: A Mitre you know
Is divided above, but united below;
If this you consider, our Emblem is right,
The B──ps divide, but the Clergy unite.
Should the Bottom be split, our Prelates may dread
The Mitre could never stick fast on their Head.
And yet they have learnt the chief Art of Sov'reign,
As Machiavel taught them,── Divide, and you govern.
But Courage, my Lords, tho' it can't be said,
That one Cloven Tongue ever sat on your Head,
I'll hold you a Groat, and I wish I cou'd see't,
If your Hose they were off, you could show Cloven Feet.
But hold, cry the B──ps, and give us fair Play,
Before you condemn us, hear what we can say:
What truer Affection could ever be shewn
Than saving your Souls by damning our own;
And have we not practis'd all Methods to gain you,
With the Tythe, of the Tythe, of the Tythe, to maintain you?
Provided a Fund for building your Spittles,
Wherein you're to live, but four Years without Vict'als.
Consenting good Lords, but let us change Hands,
First take you the Tythes, and give us your Lands.
So God bless the Church, and three of our Mitres,
And God bless the Commons for biting the Biters.
